title: How to Make Whole Wheat Sugar Cookies

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and prepare baking sheets.
steps.description: Turn on the oven to 350 degrees F (175 C). Get out a few baking sheets and tear out several sheets of parchment paper. Lay one piece of parchment paper on each baking sheet. Set the prepared sheets aside while you make the cookies. If you don't have parchment paper, you could also use a silicone baking mat.

steps.headline: Whisk together the dry ingredients.
steps.description: Mix together the dry ingredients in a medium sized bowl. You'll need to whisk 2 cups (260 g) of whole-wheat flour, 1/2 teaspoon of salt, and 1/4 teaspoon of baking powder until they're combined. Set the dry mixture aside. Whisk the ingredients for at least 30 seconds. This ensures that the baking powder is evenly distributed among the flour.

steps.headline: Cream the butter, sugar, and cream cheese.
steps.description: Place 10 tablespoons (142 g) of softened butter, 1/2 cup (100 g) of granulated sugar, and 1 ounce (30 g) of softened cream cheese into a large mixing bowl. Use a stand or electric mixer to beat the ingredients on high speed for several minutes. The mixture should look light and fluffy. Your butter and cream cheese must be soft. If they're still cold, they won't cream and you'll have lumps in the cookie dough.

steps.headline: Add the egg and vanilla.
steps.description: Turn the mixer down to low speed and add 1 large egg and 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract to the creamed butter, cream cheese, and sugar mixture. Beat the mixture until the egg and vanilla are completely combined. If you'd like to flavor the cookies with something else, consider leaving out the vanilla extract. Instead, you could use almond, lemon, peppermint, or orange extract.

steps.headline: Combine and chill the whole-wheat sugar cookie dough.
steps.description: Keep the mixer running on low speed and slowly add the dry ingredients. Beat the sugar cookie dough just until it's combined and you no longer see pockets of flour. Scoop the dough onto plastic wrap and shape it into a disk. Wrap the disk in plastic wrap and refrigerate it for one hour. Chilling is important because it will make the cookies easier to roll and will prevent them from being tough.

steps.headline: Roll and cut out the cookies.
steps.description: Sprinkle your work surface with a little bit of flour. Remove the chilled dough from the fridge and roll the disk until it's 1/4-inch (6 mm) thick. Use cookie cutters to stamp out cookies from the dough. Reroll the scraps and keep cutting out cookies until you've used all of the dough. You should get about 32 cookies. Use cookie cutters that are about 2 to 3-inches (5 to 7 cm) in size.

steps.headline: Bake the cookies.
steps.description: Arrange the cookie cutouts on the prepared baking sheets. Ensure that there's at least 1-inch (2.5 cm) of space between each cookie so they have room to expand as they bake. Bake the cookies for about 12 minutes. Remove them from the oven and let them cool completely on a wire rack. The cookies should be lightly brown around the edges once they've finished cooking.

steps.headline: Consider frosting the cookies.
steps.description: For a really simple frosting, place powdered sugar into a small mixing bowl. Add a little bit of milk or cream to the sugar and stir it with a fork until the sugar dissolves. Adjust the liquid to get a spreadable frosting consistency. Frost the cookies once they're totally cool. You can also tint the frosting different colors. Consider using food gel so that it won't make the frosting too runny. EXPERT TIP																															Mathew Rice																Professional Baker & Dessert Influencer								Mathew Rice has worked in restaurant pastry kitchens across the country since the late 1990's. His creations have been featured in Food & Wine, Bon Appetit, and Martha Stewart Weddings. In 2016, Eater named Mathew one of the top 18 chefs to follow on Instagram. Mathew Rice			Professional Baker & Dessert Influencer				Expert Tip: According to pastry chef, Mathew Rice, "If you want to glaze the cookies, I would suggest drizzling the glaze over the cookies with a pastry bag. It will look very neat this way."

methods.name: Making Easy Whole Wheat Sugar Cookies

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and get out your baking sheets.
steps.description: Turn on the oven to 375 degrees F (175 C). You'll need to have a few baking sheets ready to put the cookies on. You won't need to grease or spray the baking sheets. If your cookies frequently stick to the pans, consider laying a sheet of parchment paper on the pans.

steps.headline: Measure and combine most of the dough ingredients.
steps.description:
Since this easy whole wheat sugar cookie recipe comes together in one large mixing bowl, just measure out the most of the dough ingredients into the bowl. Beat them with an electric mixer on medium speed until they're combined. You'll need:
1 cup (200 g) of granulated sugar
1 teaspoon of baking powder
½ teaspoon of salt
½ teaspoon of ground nutmeg
½ teaspoon of baking soda
2 tablespoons (30 ml) of milk
1 tablespoon of lemon or orange zest
1 teaspoon of vanilla
½ cup (113 g) of butter, softened
1 egg

steps.headline: Stir in the flour and finish mixing the dough.
steps.description: Turn the mixer speed down to low and gradually stir in 2 cups (260 g) of whole-wheat flour. Mix the dough together until the flour is incorporated and you don't see any dry pockets. Avoid over mixing the dough since this can make the cookies tough.

steps.headline: Roll the cookies into balls.
steps.description: Use a cookie scoop or two teaspoons to measure out a few tablespoons of dough. Roll each portion of dough between the palms of your hands to make a smooth ball of dough. Place all of the balls of dough on the ungreased cookie sheets and leave about 2-inches (5 cm) of space in between them. Each ball should be about 1-inch (2.5 cm) in size.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the cookies with cinnamon-sugar.
steps.description: Use the palm of your hand or a glass to slightly flatten each ball of dough a little. Mix together the remaining 2 tablespoons of sugar and 1/2 teaspoon of cinnamon in a small bowl. Sprinkle the cinnamon-sugar mixture over the cookies. You could also play around with the flavors. Try substituting ground nutmeg or cocoa for the cinnamon.

steps.headline: Bake the whole wheat sugar cookies.
steps.description: Place the cookies in the preheated oven and bake them for 8 to 10 minutes. The cookies should puff up and crack a little bit once they're baked. They'll also turn light brown around the edges. Remove them from the oven and let them cool on a wire rack. If you have to bake the cookies in batches, avoid placing cold cookie dough on hot baking sheets. Let the sheets cool completely before using them again.

tyn: Measuring spoons and cups or digital scale
text:
Making Whole Wheat Cut-Out Cookies Preheat the oven and prepare baking sheets. Turn on the oven to 350 degrees F (175 C). Get out a few baking sheets and tear out several sheets of parchment paper. Lay one piece of parchment paper on each baking sheet. Set the prepared sheets aside while you make the cookies. If you don't have parchment paper, you could also use a silicone baking mat. Whisk together the dry ingredients. Mix together the dry ingredients in a medium sized bowl. You'll need to whisk 2 cups (260 g) of whole-wheat flour, 1/2 teaspoon of salt, and 1/4 teaspoon of baking powder until they're combined. Set the dry mixture aside. Whisk the ingredients for at least 30 seconds. This ensures that the baking powder is evenly distributed among the flour. Cream the butter, sugar, and cream cheese. Place 10 tablespoons (142 g) of softened butter, 1/2 cup (100 g) of granulated sugar, and 1 ounce (30 g) of softened cream cheese into a large mixing bowl. Use a stand or electric mixer to beat the ingredients on high speed for several minutes. The mixture should look light and fluffy. Your butter and cream cheese must be soft. If they're still cold, they won't cream and you'll have lumps in the cookie dough. Add the egg and vanilla. Turn the mixer down to low speed and add 1 large egg and 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract to the creamed butter, cream cheese, and sugar mixture. Beat the mixture until the egg and vanilla are completely combined. If you'd like to flavor the cookies with something else, consider leaving out the vanilla extract. Instead, you could use almond, lemon, peppermint, or orange extract. Combine and chill the whole-wheat sugar cookie dough. Keep the mixer running on low speed and slowly add the dry ingredients. Beat the sugar cookie dough just until it's combined and you no longer see pockets of flour. Scoop the dough onto plastic wrap and shape it into a disk. Wrap the disk in plastic wrap and refrigerate it for one hour. Chilling is important because it will make the cookies easier to roll and will prevent them from being tough. Roll and cut out the cookies. Sprinkle your work surface with a little bit of flour. Remove the chilled dough from the fridge and roll the disk until it's 1/4-inch (6 mm) thick. Use cookie cutters to stamp out cookies from the dough. Reroll the scraps and keep cutting out cookies until you've used all of the dough. You should get about 32 cookies. Use cookie cutters that are about 2 to 3-inches (5 to 7 cm) in size. Bake the cookies. Arrange the cookie cutouts on the prepared baking sheets. Ensure that there's at least 1-inch (2.5 cm) of space between each cookie so they have room to expand as they bake. Bake the cookies for about 12 minutes. Remove them from the oven and let them cool completely on a wire rack. The cookies should be lightly brown around the edges once they've finished cooking. Consider frosting the cookies. For a really simple frosting, place powdered sugar into a small mixing bowl. Add a little bit of milk or cream to the sugar and stir it with a fork until the sugar dissolves. Adjust the liquid to get a spreadable frosting consistency. Frost the cookies once they're totally cool. You can also tint the frosting different colors. Consider using food gel so that it won't make the frosting too runny. His creations have been featured in Food & Wine, Bon Appetit, and Martha Stewart Weddings. In 2016, Eater named Mathew one of the top 18 chefs to follow on Instagram. Mathew Rice			Professional Baker & Dessert Influencer				Expert Tip: According to pastry chef, Mathew Rice, "If you want to glaze the cookies, I would suggest drizzling the glaze over the cookies with a pastry bag. It will look very neat this way." Making Easy Whole Wheat Sugar Cookies Preheat the oven and get out your baking sheets. Turn on the oven to 375 degrees F (175 C). You'll need to have a few baking sheets ready to put the cookies on. You won't need to grease or spray the baking sheets. If your cookies frequently stick to the pans, consider laying a sheet of parchment paper on the pans. Measure and combine most of the dough ingredients. Since this easy whole wheat sugar cookie recipe comes together in one large mixing bowl, just measure out the most of the dough ingredients into the bowl. Beat them with an electric mixer on medium speed until they're combined. You'll need:
1 cup (200 g) of granulated sugar
1 teaspoon of baking powder
½ teaspoon of salt
½ teaspoon of ground nutmeg
½ teaspoon of baking soda
2 tablespoons (30 ml) of milk
1 tablespoon of lemon or orange zest
1 teaspoon of vanilla
½ cup (113 g) of butter, softened
1 egg Stir in the flour and finish mixing the dough. Turn the mixer speed down to low and gradually stir in 2 cups (260 g) of whole-wheat flour. Mix the dough together until the flour is incorporated and you don't see any dry pockets. Avoid over mixing the dough since this can make the cookies tough. Roll the cookies into balls. Use a cookie scoop or two teaspoons to measure out a few tablespoons of dough. Roll each portion of dough between the palms of your hands to make a smooth ball of dough. Place all of the balls of dough on the ungreased cookie sheets and leave about 2-inches (5 cm) of space in between them. Each ball should be about 1-inch (2.5 cm) in size. Sprinkle the cookies with cinnamon-sugar. Use the palm of your hand or a glass to slightly flatten each ball of dough a little. Mix together the remaining 2 tablespoons of sugar and 1/2 teaspoon of cinnamon in a small bowl. Sprinkle the cinnamon-sugar mixture over the cookies. You could also play around with the flavors. Try substituting ground nutmeg or cocoa for the cinnamon. Bake the whole wheat sugar cookies. Place the cookies in the preheated oven and bake them for 8 to 10 minutes. The cookies should puff up and crack a little bit once they're baked. They'll also turn light brown around the edges. Remove them from the oven and let them cool on a wire rack. If you have to bake the cookies in batches, avoid placing cold cookie dough on hot baking sheets. Let the sheets cool completely before using them again.

Turn on the oven to 350 degrees F (175 C).
Get out a few baking sheets and tear out several sheets of parchment paper.
Lay one piece of parchment paper on each baking sheet.
Set the prepared sheets aside while you make the cookies.
If you don't have parchment paper, you could also use a silicone baking mat.
Whisk together the dry ingredients.
Mix together the dry ingredients in a medium sized bowl.
You'll need to whisk 2 cups (260 g) of whole-wheat flour, 1/2 teaspoon of salt, and 1/4 teaspoon of baking powder until they're combined.
Set the dry mixture aside.
Whisk the ingredients for at least 30 seconds.
This ensures that the baking powder is evenly distributed among the flour.
Cream the butter, sugar, and cream cheese.
Place 10 tablespoons (142 g) of softened butter, 1/2 cup (100 g) of granulated sugar, and 1 ounce (30 g) of softened cream cheese into a large mixing bowl.
Use a stand or electric mixer to beat the ingredients on high speed for several minutes.
The mixture should look light and fluffy.
Your butter and cream cheese must be soft.
If they're still cold, they won't cream and you'll have lumps in the cookie dough.
Add the egg and vanilla.
Turn the mixer down to low speed and add 1 large egg and 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract to the creamed butter, cream cheese, and sugar mixture.
Beat the mixture until the egg and vanilla are completely combined.
If you'd like to flavor the cookies with something else, consider leaving out the vanilla extract.
Instead, you could use almond, lemon, peppermint, or orange extract.
Combine and chill the whole-wheat sugar cookie dough.
Keep the mixer running on low speed and slowly add the dry ingredients.
Beat the sugar cookie dough just until it's combined and you no longer see pockets of flour.
Scoop the dough onto plastic wrap and shape it into a disk.
Wrap the disk in plastic wrap and refrigerate it for one hour.
Chilling is important because it will make the cookies easier to roll and will prevent them from being tough.
Roll and cut out the cookies.
Sprinkle your work surface with a little bit of flour.
Remove the chilled dough from the fridge and roll the disk until it's 1/4-inch (6 mm) thick.
Use cookie cutters to stamp out cookies from the dough.
Reroll the scraps and keep cutting out cookies until you've used all of the dough.
You should get about 32 cookies.
Use cookie cutters that are about 2 to 3-inches (5 to 7 cm) in size.
Bake the cookies.
Arrange the cookie cutouts on the prepared baking sheets.
Ensure that there's at least 1-inch (2.5 cm) of space between each cookie so they have room to expand as they bake.
Bake the cookies for about 12 minutes.
Remove them from the oven and let them cool completely on a wire rack.
The cookies should be lightly brown around the edges once they've finished cooking.
Consider frosting the cookies.
For a really simple frosting, place powdered sugar into a small mixing bowl.
Add a little bit of milk or cream to the sugar and stir it with a fork until the sugar dissolves.
Adjust the liquid to get a spreadable frosting consistency.
Frost the cookies once they're totally cool.
You can also tint the frosting different colors.
Consider using food gel so that it won't make the frosting too runny.

It will look very neat this way."
Making Easy Whole Wheat Sugar Cookies Preheat the oven and get out your baking sheets.
Turn on the oven to 375 degrees F (175 C).
You'll need to have a few baking sheets ready to put the cookies on.
You won't need to grease or spray the baking sheets.
If your cookies frequently stick to the pans, consider laying a sheet of parchment paper on the pans.
Measure and combine most of the dough ingredients.
Since this easy whole wheat sugar cookie recipe comes together in one large mixing bowl, just measure out the most of the dough ingredients into the bowl.
Beat them with an electric mixer on medium speed until they're combined.

You'll need:
1 cup (200 g) of granulated sugar
1 teaspoon of baking powder
½ teaspoon of salt
½ teaspoon of ground nutmeg
½ teaspoon of baking soda
2 tablespoons (30 ml) of milk
1 tablespoon of lemon or orange zest
1 teaspoon of vanilla
½ cup (113 g) of butter, softened
1 egg Stir in the flour and finish mixing the dough.
Turn the mixer speed down to low and gradually stir in 2 cups (260 g) of whole-wheat flour.
Mix the dough together until the flour is incorporated and you don't see any dry pockets.
Avoid over mixing the dough since this can make the cookies tough.
Roll the cookies into balls.
Use a cookie scoop or two teaspoons to measure out a few tablespoons of dough.
Roll each portion of dough between the palms of your hands to make a smooth ball of dough.
Place all of the balls of dough on the ungreased cookie sheets and leave about 2-inches (5 cm) of space in between them.
Each ball should be about 1-inch (2.5 cm) in size.
Sprinkle the cookies with cinnamon-sugar.
Use the palm of your hand or a glass to slightly flatten each ball of dough a little.
Mix together the remaining 2 tablespoons of sugar and 1/2 teaspoon of cinnamon in a small bowl.
Sprinkle the cinnamon-sugar mixture over the cookies.
You could also play around with the flavors.
Try substituting ground nutmeg or cocoa for the cinnamon.
Bake the whole wheat sugar cookies.
Place the cookies in the preheated oven and bake them for 8 to 10 minutes.
The cookies should puff up and crack a little bit once they're baked.
They'll also turn light brown around the edges.
Remove them from the oven and let them cool on a wire rack.
If you have to bake the cookies in batches, avoid placing cold cookie dough on hot baking sheets.
Let the sheets cool completely before using them again.
